Upon completion, the Project will benefit about 147,000 residential 
users, industries, and small businesses in the three towns. About 
50%  of  the  towns’  populations  are  poor  families.  Access  to  safe

improved  hygiene  and  health  conditions,  and  environmental

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector in Azerbaijan is characterized by institutional 
weaknesses,  inefficient  operations,  outdated  and  dilapidated  physical  infrastructure,  and  severe 
financial  constraints.  As  a  result,  consumers  receive  a  low  level  and  poor  quality  WSS  services. 
Until  recently,  the  WSS  sector  consisted  of  the  Greater  Baku  and  the  Apsheron peninsular  area, 
which  was  served  by  the  Joint  Stock  Company  (JSC)  Apsheron  Regional  Water  Company 
(ARWC); and all urban and rural communities outside the Apsheron peninsula, which came under 
the  overall  responsibility  of  the  Azersukanaltemir  Production  Union  (commonly  known  as 
AzerSuKanal), a department within the State Committee for Construction and Architecture (SCCA). 
The focus of this Project is on the WSS sector in the secondary towns.1  
 
3. 
In  June  2004,  Presidential  Decree  (PD)  252  was  issued,  titled  “On  Improvement  of  the 
Water  Supply  Management  in  the  Azerbaijan  Republic.”  In  the  part  that  relates  to  the  proposed 
Project, the PD indicated that (i) the JSC ARWC is to be renamed and reorganized into the JSC 
AzerSu  (AzerSu);  and  (ii)  the  AzerSuKanal  of  SCCA  is  liquidated,  and  its  functions  and  assets 
transferred to the AzerSu.2  
 
Administrative  Structure.  AzerSuKanal  had  51  local  branches  (water  and  wastewater

Level and Quality of WSS Services. The water supply to consumers is intermittent and of 
limited quantity. The water quality is poor, with high levels of silt. Many consumers buy water from 
private  vendors  to  augment  their  supply.  Similarly,  sewerage  systems  are  failing,  and  pipes  are 
clogged and broken. During heavy rains raw sewage floods the streets and house compounds, and 
existing  treatment  facilities  do  not  operate.  River  pollution  increases,  and  stagnant  sewage 
threatens health conditions.

B. 

Analysis of Problems and Opportunities 

12. 
The  proposed  Project  is  ADB’s  first  intervention  in  Azerbaijan’s  WSS  sector.  Project 
preparation  started  with  an  assessment  of  WSS  sectors  in  secondary  towns.  The  Government 
identified  15  towns  for  initial  screening  and  assessment  of  WSS  conditions.  Data  were  collected 
and analyzed, followed by field visits and interviews. The following criteria were used to rank the 
towns: (i) maximum impact on poverty reduction, (ii) preliminary analysis of investment alternatives 
and  their  cost  effectiveness,  (iii)  prospects  of  cost  recovery  and  financial  sustainability,  (iv)  local 
governments’  commitment  and  availability  of  counterpart  funds,  and  (v)  coordination  with  other 
international  lending  organizations.  Based  on  weighted  scores,  three  towns—Agdash,  Goychay, 
and Nakhchivan (project towns)—were selected for further feasibility studies.9  
 
13. 
The WSS sector analysis in the secondary towns, undertaken during the first phase of the 
project preparatory TA, has benefited from the detailed feasibility studies in the three towns. The 
completed  WSS  sector  analysis  included  recommendations  for  sector  reform  in  the  secondary 
towns. The undertaken sector analysis highlighted the following key issues: 
  

(i)  There is insufficient autonomy at the local level to operate, maintain, and manage the WSS 
systems.  The  lack  of  autonomy  and  dependence  on  others  for  vital  decisions  impede  the 
senses of ownership, initiative, responsibility, and accountability, which are the foundations

particularly  relevant:  (i)  without  institutional  reforms,  the  likelihood  of  success  of  significant

including  the  water  source,  water  treatment  if  applicable,  distribution,  and  wastewater  collection

conditions  in  small  towns,  PSP  with  equity  investments  by  foreign  private  operators  may  be

28. 
Alternative  technical  options  were  analyzed  during  Project  preparation,  and  the  proposed 
options are least-cost in economic terms. For the water source, the development of new borehole 
fields in Agdash and Goychay was compared with a number of options, including reinstatement of 
the presently destroyed infiltration galleries.17 Hydrogeological analyses of alluvial cones concluded 
that  the  proposed  well  fields  have  adequate  supply  of  good  quality  water  over  the  project  life.  In 
Nakhchivan, the existing infiltration galleries represent a good and reliable source compared with 
the alternative of developing new sources.

and  upgrade  the  system  in  Nakhchivan.  The  proposed  schemes  will  also  improve  pressure

Institutional  Reform  and  Capacity  Building.  Alternative  institutional  options  were

summarizes the risks, advantages, and disadvantages of these alternatives. 
 
32. 
The  institutional  reform  and  capacity  building  component  will  establish  a  JSC  in  each 
project town to provide efficient and financially viable operations. The Agdash and Goychay JSCs 
will  be  subsidiary  companies  of  AzerSu,  whose  shares  belong  to  the  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development  (MED).19  The  new  status  and  identity  of  the  utilities  will  provide  a  foundation  for 
independence  in  ownership,  operation,  and  management  of  the  assets.  In  the  future,  it  will  also 
allow parties other than the central government to acquire an interest in, and responsibility for, the 
utility.  
 
33. 
The  JSCs  will  (i)  own  assets  constructed  and  rehabilitated  under  the  Project,  and  be 
responsible  for  the  operation,  management,  and  maintenance  of  the  WSS  systems;  (ii)  have 
appropriate autonomy in financial, managerial, operational, and staffing decisions; and (iii) report to 
AzerSu in Agdash and Goychay, and to SCCA of NAR in Nakhchivan, and be accountable for their 
performances.  To  preserve  the  operational  integrity  and  financial  viability  of  the  new  JSCs  in 
Agdash and Goychay, it is essential that neither old physical assets from the SuKanals, nor any of 
their outstanding debts and liabilities, be transferred to the new JSCs.  
 
34. 
Each  JSC  will  have  a  board  of  directors.  The  details  of  the  institutional  and  legal 
arrangements for the JSCs, as well as the composition of their boards, will be developed under the 
advisory  TA  associated  with  the  Project.  To  ensure  local  participation  in  the  WSS  services,  a 
meaningful proportion of the board’s voting rights will be assigned to the municipalities. The board 
will  determine  policies  on  supply  and  delivery  of  WSS  services,  staff,  capital  investments,  O&M 
budgets, customer relations, and tariffs.  
 
35. 
The capacities of the JSCs will be developed through on-the-job training by the MC during 
initial  operational  years  of  the  new  systems.  Upon  formation  of  the  JSCs,  the  SuKanals  will  be 
disbanded and liquidated. During the construction period, the JSCs will operate the existing assets, 
which will be phased out and decommissioned as the new assets become operational.

37. 
The Project supports the Government’s ongoing efforts  to reform the WSS sector, and will 
help  shape  and  direct  those  reforms.  The  existing  institutional  framework  in  WSS  for  secondary 
towns is unsustainable; it should be expected to result in low-quality construction of the proposed 
physical  infrastructure,  continued  ineffective  operation,  maintenance,  and  management  of  WSS 
assets,  and  thus,  no  significant  improvements  in  WSS  services.  The  Project  will  pilot-test 
approaches  for  the  WSS  sector,  as  a  basis  for  sector-wide  reforms  in  the  country’s  secondary 
towns.  
 
38. 
The MC will bring international expertise to the operation, maintenance, and management 
of  the  new  WSS  facilities,  and  train  local  staff  to  assume  full  responsibility  for  operating  the 
systems. Among several options considered,20 the MC option was chosen as the most appropriate 
way  to  build  capacity  of  the  new  JSCs  and  transfer  some  initial  operating  risks  to  the  MC.  The 
transaction adviser under the associated TA will advise and guide on the form, scope, conditions, 
procurement procedures, duration, performance criteria, and fee structure of the MC.21 The JSCs 
will  appoint  the  MC,  and  the  transaction  adviser  and  the  project  management  units  (PMUs)  will 
provide  technical  support  during  recruitment,  particularly  for  preparing  terms  of  reference,  short-
listing  of  potential  firms,  evaluation  and  ranking  of  proposals,  and  negotiating  MC  with  selected 
firm(s). The MC will provide two key personnel, a chief engineer-operations manager and a finance 
manager.  The  MC  will  become  effective  about  1  year  before  the  physical  construction  work  is 
completed,  to  enable  them  to  become  familiar  with  the  WSS  systems  as  they  are  constructed; 
select  counterpart  staff;  and  set  up  the  operational,  administrative,  and  financial  management 
systems for the JSCs. The JSCs, the Government, and ADB will review future arrangements during 
the last year of the contract. 
  
39. 
The second innovative feature of the Project relates to promotion of local participation and 
consumer interest in WSS services. The Project will have municipalities represented on the boards 
of  the  JSCs,  and  will  establish  town  water  users’  associations  (TWUAs).  A  fixed  share  of  the 
boards’  voting  rights  will  be  assigned  to  the  representatives  of  municipalities,  to  ensure  local 
participation in the WSS services. TWUAs will be formed in two project towns as advocacy groups 
to  represent  consumer  interests.  The  JSCs  will  recognize  the  TWUAs  as  important  partners  in 
ensuring that WSS services satisfy the consumers. ADB will provide grant support for this pilot and 
demonstration  activity  (PDA),  which  will  strengthen  local  partnership  for  managing  WSS  services 
(Supplementary Appendix 8).22

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

62. 
Economic Aspects. Urban WSS services in the project towns are inadequate. Assets have 
deteriorated  and  a  lack  of  maintenance  has  severely  affected  service  delivery.  Without  major 
investments  in  the  near  future  the  WSS  systems  will  continue  to  deteriorate  rapidly,  with  serious 
consequences for economic activity, livelihood, hygiene, and health. The water supply systems in 
Agdash  and  Goychay  are  approaching  total  collapse.  All  three  project  towns  ration  water,  with 
many  residents  (ranging  between  22%  to  54%)  having  to  use  alternative  water  sources  for  their 

 

 14

 

 

main  water  supply.  The  social  survey  found  that  residents  ranked  improvements  in  the  WSS 
systems as a high priority to improve quality of their lives. Upon completion, the Project will benefit 
about 147,000 residential users, industries, and small businesses in the three towns. Access to a 
safe  and  reliable  water  supply  and  properly  operating  sewerage  and  wastewater  treatment 
systems will benefit the poor and non-poor alike, as they are not geographically separated, and all 
households will have access to the improved system.  
 
63. 
The WSS component will (i) provide safe and reliable drinking water, including to extended 
service  areas;  (ii)  generate  major  efficiency  gains  by  providing  systems  that  are  more  properly 
sized to demand requirements, will reduce system losses, and will reduce staff and maintenance 
costs; (iii) improve cost recovery through better customer satisfaction; (iv) improve the health and 
well-being  of  the  people  in  three  secondary  towns  through  reduced  water-related  diseases  and 
better  hygiene;  (v)  reduce  the  cost  of,  and  time  spent  on,  water  collection,  storage,  boiling,  and 
other treatment, particularly for women; and (vi) support economic recovery and growth. UFW will 
be  reduced  in  Agdash  and  Goychay  from  the  currently  estimated  70%  to  25%  with  the  major 
replacement of the water supply transmission and distribution systems, and in Nakhchivan to about 
50% through leak detection and improved management of the distribution system. 
 
64. 
An  analysis  of  alternative  water  sources  was  undertaken  and  least-cost  development 
options were identified. In Agdash and Goychay the development of new borehole fields for each 
town  was  compared  with  other  options,  including  reinstatement  of  the  present  washed-out 
infiltration galleries. The capital and operating costs of the borehole fields were found to be least 
cost  when  compared  with  capital  costs  of  having  to  reinstate  and  protect  the  infiltration  gallery 
infrastructures.  Also,  to  make  this  option  viable,  additional  institutional  arrangements  would  be 
necessary to better manage the river catchment. For Nakhchivan, the existing infiltration galleries 
represent  a  good  and  reliable  source  compared  with  the  alternative  of  developing  new  sources. 
The  sewage  treatment  works  in  each  town  do  not  function,  and  raw  sewage  is  discharged  into 
rivers. Advantages and disadvantages of alternative options for treating sewage were considered. 
WSPs  were  chosen  because  of  the  low  capital  requirements,  available  municipal  land,  and  low 
operating costs with low energy and chemical requirements.  
 
65. 
A forecast of demand for WSS services was undertaken, based on least-cost options and 
corresponding  optimal  tariffs.  The  demand  estimates  were  used  to  determine  the  optimal  design 
capacity of the WSS systems and the justified scale of investment. The economic internal rate of 
return  (EIRR)  was  calculated  in  constant  2004  prices  using  the  domestic  price  numeraire,  since 
project  outputs  are  non-tradables.  Costs  include  capital  costs  in  line  with  the  implementation 
schedule,  and  operating  and  replacement  costs.  Financial  costs,  excluding  taxes  and  duties,  are 
converted to economic costs by applying a shadow exchange rate factor and a shadow wage rate 
factor for unskilled labor. Nonincremental economic benefits include considerations of (i) purchase 
of  tankered  water;  (ii)  use  of  boreholes;  (iii)  time  savings  for  water  collection;  (iv)  costs  of  water 
storage, disinfecting, and pumping; and (v) water boiling and filtering costs.  
 
66. 
The  overall  project  EIRR  is  21.8%.  The  EIRR  for  Agdash  is  25.5%;  for  Goychay,  24.8%; 
and for Nakhchivan, 18.7%. Thus the EIRR for the three towns exceeds the economic opportunity 
cost  of  capital,  which  is  assumed  to  be  12%.  The  calculations  do  not  include  external  benefits 
related  to  improved  hygiene  and  health,  and  environmental  benefits  from  improved  sewage 
collection  and  treatment.  Accordingly,  the  assessment  of  benefits  should  be  treated  as 
conservative.  Sensitivity  tests  were  undertaken  to  consider  the  impact  of  risks,  encompassed  in 
adverse cost and benefit scenarios. Sensitivity indicators and switching values were calculated for 
the standard sensitivity tests. Under all sensitivity tests, the subprojects were found economically 
viable. Appendix 11 summarizes the economic analyses.

67. 
Tariffs  and  Affordability.  The  following  objectives  were  taken  into  account  when 
considering water and wastewater tariffs and their structures: (i) financial sustainability and full cost 
recovery, (ii) economic efficiency and marginal costs, (iii) price equity, (iv) administrative efficiency 
and good governance, and (iv) affordability and universal access.24  
 
In developing tariffs and financial objectives for the new JSCs, special emphasis was given 
68. 
to ensuring long-term financial sustainability of services, while simultaneously ensuring that tariffs 
are affordable, especially for low-income and at-risk households. On the basis of discussions with 
the  local  and  central  governments  and  project  household  surveys,  the  basic  WSS  needs  in  the 
secondary towns were defined as 45 lpcd. Tariffs are regarded as affordable where the payments 
for the WSS services do not exceed 5% of household income. Based on estimates of such tariffs, 
the JSCs are able to meet the O&M costs and to repay a major portion of the ADB loans allocated 
for the water supply component. 
  
69. 
Current water tariffs are low and customer resistance to paying water bills is high because 
of  poor  services.  After  project  commissioning  and  provision  of  24-hour  supply,  tariffs  will  be 
increased  by  two  or  three  times  in  2008,  and  then  raised  another  50%  in  two  steps  by  2012. 
Afterward, tariffs will be maintained in real terms, adjusting for inflation. The analysis described in 
Appendix 12 shows the tariff levels proposed for each project town and demonstrates that they are 
affordable.  The  proposed  average  household  charges  were  compared  with  average  household 
income in 2012. The results are 4.8% in Agdash, 4.6% in Goychay, and 3.5% in Nakhchivan. For 
low-income residents, proposed charges for basic needs of 45 lpcd are 4.2% in Agdash, 3.0% in 
Goychay,  and  2.3%  in  Nakhchivan.  Furthermore,  the  combined  monthly  charges  for  water  and 
wastewater  are  far  less  than  the  estimated  coping  costs  of  households  required  to  obtain  their 
monthly  water  supplies  (involving  purchase  of  water,  fetching,  storing,  pumping,  and  boiling  and 
filtering). To address the social implications of the increased WSS tariffs, a public awareness and 
education  campaign  will  be  undertaken  through  the  MC  activities,  associated  TA,  and  the  grant 
assistance to the TWUAs through PDA. 
 
70. 
Financial Analysis. Financial projections were prepared for each new JSC, assuming  that 
the  new  entities  will  take  over  operation  of  existing  systems  during  the  construction  phase. 
Financial  projections,  including  operating  and  financial  ratios,  have  been  prepared  in  nominal 
terms. Estimates of O&M costs consider improvements in efficiency from optimally sized systems 
compared  with  the  existing  systems,  which  were  oversized.  Financial  projections  also  assume 
improved  cash  flow  management,  including  higher  collection  rates,  which  should  be  achieved 
through MC activities. After 2008, the JSCs are expected to meet cash flow requirements and after 
2012,  to  meet  full  debt  service  obligations  and  maintain  a  minimum  debt  service  ratio  of  1.2. 
Appendix 13 summarizes financial analysis.  
 
71. 
A  financial  evaluation,  in  real  terms  using  constant  2004  prices,  was  completed  for  each 
subproject. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms were converted to 
real  terms  by  adjusting  for  the  likely  effects  of  foreign  and  domestic  inflation  and  currency 
fluctuation. Incremental costs and benefits were derived by evaluating the financial positions of the 
JSCs  under  “with  project”  and  “without  project”  scenarios.  The  average  financial  internal  rate  of 
return (FIRR) is 4.4%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital of 1.3%. 
The  Project  is  considered  both  financially  viable  and  sustainable.  Sensitivity  and  risk  analyses 
indicate that the FIRR for each subproject and the project overall are robust under most conditions.

The economic analysis is undertaken for the combined water supply and sanitation (WSS) 
components  in  each  of  the  project  towns.  The  analysis  describes  the  economic  rationale,  the 
“without-project”  situation,  project  benefits,  and  the  least-cost  analysis  of  alternatives  where 
applicable.  Based on the least-cost options, a tariff pricing policy was developed with emphasis on 
financial sustainability of the WSS services, and their affordability to the vulnerable groups to meet 
their basic needs. Further, water demand forecasts were developed on the basis of the proposed 
changes  in  the  WSS  tariffs,  taking  into  account  price  elasticity  of  demand  of  -0.35  and  income 
elasticity of demand of 0.50. The analysis was based on the combined water and sewerage tariffs. 
These demand estimates1 were then adjusted for budget and commercial/industrial consumption, 
plus seasonal and daily peaking factors, and were used to determine the optimal design capacity 
of the WSS systems and thus the justified scale of the investment. Capacity of the WSS systems 
was designed for a 15-year planning horizon. 
 
3. 
The  analysis  compared  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  to  the  economic 
opportunity  cost  of  capital  (EOCC),  which  is  assumed  to  be  12%.  Sensitivity  analyses  were 
undertaken  for  standard  sensitivity  tests  and  for  project  specific  risks.  A  distribution  analysis  of 
project benefits was prepared and the poverty impact ratio (PIR) calculated. The analysis adopted 
the  domestic  price  numeraire,  since  benefits  are  non-tradable  in  nature,  and  was  undertaken  in 
constant  2004  prices.  The  analysis  was  undertaken  over  a  30-year  period,  with  benefits  held 
constant from year 15 with no residual values assumed at the end of the period. 
 
B. 
 
4. 
The  urban  WSS  has  suffered  many  years  of  neglect  since  independence.  Assets  have 
deteriorated and lack of proper maintenance is such that service delivery in the three project towns 
is severely affected. Without major investment in the near future the WSS systems will continue to 
deteriorate  rapidly  and  approach  a  state  of  collapse,  with  serious  consequences  for  economic 
activity and livelihood. All of the project towns have suffered from the loss of economic activity and 
employment  since  independence.  Although  the  outlook  is  now  more  positive  with  the  recent 
Government  emphasis  on  regional  development,  without  basic  infrastructure  improvements, 
economic recovery and growth is likely to be hampered.  
 
5. 
Household surveys in the three project towns found that the actual level of service delivery 
is poor, with 95% respondents indicating that the overriding problem is a poor quality of water with 
it’s high silt content. Some 27% of households receive water for only one or two days a week while 
20% receive it only on alternate days for 2-3 hours in all cases.  Estimates of water use indicated 
that the actual consumption is constrained by lack of reliable supply, and is estimated at around 30 
to 45 lpcd. In an unconstrained situation, the demand is estimated to be of the order of 80 to 100 
lpcd.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Azerbaijan:  
 
The secondary towns in Azerbaijan are characterized by a nonfunctional system of water supply and 
sanitation (WSS). Having inherited an infrastructure dating back to the 1960s, the system in secondary 
towns is characterized by low water quality, unreliable water availability, and overflowing ditches. The 
water shortage particularly affects the poor. Many consumers augment supply by buying water from 
private vendors. Similarly, sewerage systems are failing, pipes are clogged and broken, raw sewage 
floods the streets and house compounds during heavy rains, and treatment facilities do not work. The 
WSS service providers suffer from weak technical and financial management capability and capacity, and 
under-investment in maintenance and capital works. 
 
Access to clean water is a target of the United Nation’s Millennium Goals. This point is further stressed in 
the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) “Water for All” strategy. Even though the sector has no direct 
poverty reduction impact, the Project influences the overall quality of life of the poor. The Project aims to 
improve water service standards, thus improving people’s access to potable water, giving communities 
safe drinking water from their home taps. The Project also improves the existing sewerage systems, and 
connects all households to centralized sewerage, creating a safe and healthy environment for each 
community. This particularly benefits poorer households that have lacked access to centralized sewerage. 
The Project helps alleviate water shortages in secondary towns on a sustainable and  long-term basis, and 
thus improves the health and well-being of its inhabitants. Enhanced WSS systems lead to healthier 
communities by providing reliable access to potable water, and good sewerage systems.    
 
The Project’s primary target population is the 147,000 people living in three secondary towns of Agdash, 
Goychay, and Nakhchivan. Half are poor families. The Project will provide the population access to a safe, 
adequate, reliable, and sustainable supply of piped, potable water.  The Project will also provide access to 
effective and hygienic sanitation and wastewater disposal through individual property connections to a 
sewerage network and sewage treatment facilities. By the end of the Project, water coverage in the project 
area will increase from 55% to 80%, and sewerage coverage will increase from 43% to 77%. By 2010, an 
estimated 147,000 people will benefit from improved water supply and quality, increased quantity, 
extended service areas, more equitable water distribution, and better customer services.  These benefits 
will go hand-in-hand with higher standards of public health, hygiene, and improved sanitation facilities and 
maintenance.   
 
The survey showed that water quality is worsened by contamination from polluted shallow ground water 
and leaky distribution pipes. Poor water quality impacts sharply on public health.  Although details are not 
available, the survey suggests that the impact of water-borne diseases on morbidity and mortality rates is 
high in the project area.  The Project will reduce the incidence of diarrhea, dysentery, and skin diseases; 
and will also reduce sick time caused by water-borne diseases.   
 
The water shortage particularly impacts the poor. WSS expenses do not differ between poorer and richer 
households, which may be a consequence of the use of normative pricing rather than meters.  The survey 
indicated that the WSS costs make up a considerably higher portion of total expenditures for the poor than 
for the rich. Furthermore, people with no access to a central water supply must purchase water from 
merchants at a higher price, or go to public water sources, spending additional time and money for 
queuing, water storage, and boiling. Hardship in water management is more severe among poorer 
households, particularly among women, who are mostly responsible for water collection, storage, and 
treatment.

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Women, as the main household caretakers, are affected more than men by WSS failures. Women spend 
much time collecting water, and cleaning water for cooking, cleaning, and other household activities. 
Furthermore, women take care of children that suffer from waterborne diseases. Thus, any improvement in 
the WSS systems has direct impact on the well-being of women.  
 
The Project focused on women from the initial phase of social analysis. One finding was that women are 
more aware than men of water-related problems, and they have concrete suggestions on how to improve 
the system. Women’s preferences and suggestions have shaped the project design. Women have 
emphasized the importance of clean and reliable water through meetings with women NGOs in 
participatory focus group meetings, and random interviews. To ensure that women’s participation and 
gender concerns are fully addressed, the Project will encourage that at least 30% of TWUA members be 
female. Thus, the Project aims to fulfill women’s demands on clean and reliable water as a top priority. 
Furthermore, the awareness and education campaign on women water conservation would target an equal 
number of men and women, who would be community leaders for reducing water waste. NGOs targeted to 
women and water use will conduct special training.
